summaryText: What an incredible sermon by Pastor Travis Hearn about stepping out of our comfort zones! Pastor Travis breaks down the powerful story of Peter walking on water with Jesus, challenging us to move beyond what feels safe and familiar. Isn't it so true that we often get stuck in our 'boats' of comfort, afraid to take that step of faith? PT reminds us that our miracles are waiting on the other side of our courage! Drawing from biblical stories like Jonah running from God and Jacob and Esau's birthright narrative, he powerfully illustrates how comfort can cost us our divine calling. The most convicting moment? When he references Revelation 3 and talks about being 'lukewarm' - neither hot nor cold - and how God desires our complete surrender. Pastor Travis challenges us to go 'all in' for Jesus, not just showing up occasionally, but fully committing to our relationship with God. It's like he's saying, 'Your comfort zone is the enemy of your calling!' This message isn't just a sermon, it's a wake-up call to step out of our boats, trust God, and experience the supernatural miraculous power He has waiting for us.
mainPoints: Your miracle is on the other side of your step of faith
Comfort comes with a dangerous cost
Go all in for Jesus, not just partially committed

versesMentioned.text: About three o'clock in the morning Jesus came toward them walking on the water. When the disciples saw him walking on the water, they were terrified and in their fear they cried out, 'It's a ghost!' But Jesus spoke to them at once and said, 'Don't be afraid, take courage. It is I.'
Now the Jordan is at flood stage during harvest. Yet as soon as the priests who carried the ark reached the Jordan and their feet touched the water's edge, the water from upstream stopped flowing.

But Jonah ran away from the Lord and headed for Tarshish. He went down to Joppa, where he found a ship bound for that port. After paying the fare, he went aboard and sailed for Tarshish to flee from the Lord.
Then the Lord sent a great wind on the sea, and such a violent storm arose that the ship threatened to break up.
In trouble, deep trouble, I prayed to God and he answered me. From the belly of the grave I cried help, and you heard my cry.

I know your deeds, that you are neither cold nor hot. I wish you were either one or the other! So, because you are lukewarm—neither hot nor cold—I am about to spit you out of my mouth. You say, 'I am rich; I have acquired wealth and do not need a thing.' But you do not realize that you are wretched, pitiful, poor, blind and naked. I counsel you to buy from me gold refined in the fire, so you can become rich; and white clothes to wear, so you can cover your shameful nakedness; and salve to put on your eyes, so you can see. Those whom I love I rebuke and discipline. So be earnest and repent.

Monday.scripture: Hebrews 11:6: 'And without faith it is impossible to please God, because anyone who comes to him must believe that he exists and that he rewards those who earnestly seek him.'
Monday.focus: Identifying areas where I'm staying in my comfort zone
Monday.action: Make a list of 3 dreams or callings you've been too afraid to pursue. Pray over each one and ask God for courage to take the first step.
Monday.prayer: Lord, reveal the areas where I've been playing it safe. Give me the courage to step out in faith and trust Your guidance. Help me move beyond my comfort zone and into Your calling. Amen.

Tuesday.scripture: James 1:2-4: 'Consider it pure joy, my brothers and sisters, whenever you face trials of many kinds, because you know that the testing of your faith produces perseverance.'
Tuesday.focus: Understanding that discomfort leads to growth
Tuesday.action: Do something today that makes you uncomfortable. This could be speaking to someone new, trying a new skill, or serving in an unfamiliar way.
Tuesday.prayer: God, help me embrace discomfort as an opportunity for spiritual growth. Teach me to see challenges as chances to develop my faith. Give me courage to step out of my familiar patterns. Amen.

Wednesday.scripture: Philippians 3:13-14: 'Brothers and sisters, I do not consider myself yet to have taken hold of it. But one thing I do: Forgetting what is behind and straining toward what is ahead, I press on toward the goal to win the prize for which God has called me heavenward in Christ Jesus.'
Wednesday.action: Identify one past failure or fear that has kept you stuck. Write a letter to yourself about how you're choosing to move forward and trust God's plan.
Wednesday.prayer: Heavenly Father, help me release past fears and hesitations. Give me a fresh perspective and the courage to press forward into Your calling. Replace my fear with faith. Amen.

Thursday.scripture: Joshua 1:9: 'Have I not commanded you? Be strong and courageous. Do not be afraid; do not be discouraged, for the Lord your God will be with you wherever you go.'
Thursday.action: Make a list of 5 things you would do if you knew you could not fail. Pray over each item and ask God to give you direction.
Thursday.prayer: Lord, fill me with Your courage. Help me see beyond my limitations and trust in Your unlimited power. Guide me toward the path You've prepared. Amen.

Friday.scripture: Romans 8:28: 'And we know that in all things God works for the good of those who love him, who have been called according to his purpose.'
Friday.focus: Trusting God's plan over personal comfort
Friday.action: Reach out to someone who might need encouragement to step out of their comfort zone. Share a story of how God has worked in your life.
Friday.prayer: God, use me as an instrument of courage and faith. Help me be an encouragement to others who are struggling to trust You. Reveal Your purpose in my life. Amen.

Saturday.scripture: 2 Timothy 1:7: 'For the Spirit God gave us does not make us timid, but gives us power, love and self-discipline.'
Saturday.action: Spend time in reflection. Journal about one area where you've been playing it safe and create a specific plan to step out in faith.
Saturday.prayer: Holy Spirit, fill me with Your power and courage. Remove any spirit of fear and replace it with bold faith. Help me trust You completely and step into the calling You have for me. Amen.
